content:
I got 100% on this as a fastest clash in 12:21. I was the only one who submitted with more than 50%. I was the only one *stubborn* enough to code the whole thing.
It is incredibly boring. There is nothing at all to figure out.
The only reason to make such a puzzle is that it is easy for the author to make. There's no creativity, no challenge, no thought involved. It is only very time-consuming. 
Excel spreadsheet programming is more interesting than this.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun challenge for beginners and entertaining

There is no problem in programming I hate more than stringifying numbers. This can go so wrong at so many places that it's just insanse. If you make a type in "thirty", "twelve", "eighty", "eight" or "fifty" your validators fail and your tests pass. Does it make you a bad programmer? No. Does it make you angry? Extremely. The only way to test if this actually works is checking all numbers up to 99. And then still you will be probably mistaken as your eye won't catch small things.

Worth calling out that in Reverse you don't get a statement so the whole problem is a leap of faith on what the largest number might be in the Validators.

And lastly and this is my most important comment. Your problem assumes that everyone is familiar with the gramatically accurate way of writing numbers. And that is an unfair. Especially since it's not part of the problem statement.

These are not grounds for rejection but my opinion.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: clear, straightforward, good for beginers

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy but long. Players may reach for a lib doing it, the possible exploitations would be interesting.
Pretty fun and straightforward. Code size is going to be big, but that's the nature of the problem.
Maybe add a line of input from 'twenty' to 'ninety' to reduce the coding implementation.
Heavy implementation problem. People will most likely skip it due to long implementation of code.
Seems hard to solve within 15 mins
I really love it  but maybe try increasing the difficulty level

loved the problem you can also increase the range of the constraints to make the problem as difficult as possible..........

other than that your problem statement looks good
Most people are saying I should increases  the difficulty level but for you it's too hard. I think it is perfect
I have added the types of numbers. That seems like all I need to add. If people make typos, it means they didn't read the statement properly.

You can remove 0 as that is not a valid number according to constraints.

Can you add one more sentence:
"Numbers larger than twenty have hyphen between the tens and ones. If number is 52, output fifty-two."

The example is good.

Making a typo does not mean the person doesn't know the correct spelling.  Are you seriously claiming that you have NEVER missed a key while typing?

You can avoid most of this problem by mix-and-matching the tests to make validators. E.g. if tests are 50 and 87 then validators are 57 and 80.
